analysis:
**1. The Core Claim(s):**
The claim states that the speed of light is exactly 300,000 kilometers per second.

**2. Evidence Breakdown:**
*   The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 300,000 kilometers per second.
*   The exact value defined by the International System of Units (SI) is 299,792.458 meters per second.
*   Rounding this value often results in the approximation of 300,000 kilometers per second.

**3. Context & Nuance:**
While the speed of light is often approximated as 300,000 km/s, the exact value is 299,792.458 km/s. The claim is mostly true because it uses a common approximation. The difference between the approximation and the actual value is small.

**4. Red Flags & Discrepancies:**
No major discrepancies found in the verified sources.

grounding_citations.title: Speed of Light Explained: Physics, Speed & Optics Guide - Evident Scientific
grounding_citations.snippet:
Speed of Light Explained: Physics, Speed & Optics Guide - Evident Scientific
Light moves so fast that, for much of human history, we thought it traveled instantaneously. As early as the late 1600s, though, scientist Ole Roemer was able to measure the speed of light (usually referred to as c) by using observations of Jupiter's moons, according to Britannica.

grounding_citations.title: What is the speed of light? | Live Science
grounding_citations.snippet: (2023-05-30) Light moves at an incredible 186,000 miles per second (300,000 kilometers per second), equivalent to almost 700 million mph (more than 1 billion km/h). That's fast enough to circumnavigate the globe 7.5 times in one second, while a typical passenger jet would take more than two days to go around once (and that doesn't include stops for fuel or layovers!). ... Light moves so fast that, for much of human history, we thought it traveled instantaneously. As early as the late 1600s, though, scientist Ole Roemer was able to measure the speed of light (usually referred to as c) by using observations of Jupiter's moons, according to Britannica.

grounding_citations.title: Speed of light - Wikipedia
grounding_citations.snippet:
The value 299,792,458 metres per second is approximately 1 billion kilometres per hour; 700 million miles per hour. For other approximations of c valid for various units and size scales see the sidebar. Speed of light. The distance from the Sun to Earth is shown as 150 million kilometres, an approximate. Due to its finite speed, sunlight takes 8 minutes and 10 to 27 seconds to reach Earth, depending on the time of year.

The speed of light in vacuum, often called simply the speed of light and commonly denoted c, is a universal physical constant exactly equal to 299792458 m⋅s−1. It is exact because, by international agreement, a metre is defined as the length of the path travelled by light in vacuum during a time interval of 1⁄299792458 second. The value 299,792,458 metres per second is approximately 1 billion kilometres per hour; 700 million miles per hour. For other approximations of c valid for various units and size scales see the sidebar.
